These are very valid questions. I just had no idea where I could explain the reasoning behind it.
In general, a Kafka client does not open a single connection but rather connects to the brokers to whose partitions it sends messages, i.e. between 1 and the cluster size. Since the topics for events and telemetry do not have to be on the same brokers, on average there are not many more connections through the separate sender instances.
I see it as an advantage that the "rare but important" events do not have to wait in the same queue as the much more frequent telemetry messages. Since the messages are collected in batches before sending and are sent in sequence with retries and rather generous timeouts (the default timeout for sending is 2 minutes), I expect a lower latency for events under load.
I would also like us to have the possibility to decide later that both types of messages should be configured differently.

why do we make this configurable if we only accept org.apache.kafka.common.serialization.StringSerializer anyway?

FMPOV this is not configurable. If you have an idea of how I can make it more clear in the description here, I'll be happy to change it.
The logic is the following: every property that starts with the prefix hono.kafka.producerConfig is put into a map (without the prefix of course). The map is finally provided to the "native" Kafka client. You can add arbitrary properties there. The Kafka client applies the known properties and ignores those that it does not know. The table lists the exceptions: properties that are effectively not configurable because Hono overwrites them. You can set the command line option --hono.kafka.producerConfig.key.serializer=bumlux. Hono (i.e. the class KafkaProducerConfigProperties) will change the value of the property to org.apache.kafka.common.serialization.StringSerializer (a message about this is printed on debug level).
I don't see a way to exclude properties from that mechanism. Alternatively, Hono would have to support each Kafka client config property explicitly (which are many dozens) and would then be tied to specific versions of the client (because properties change between versions).
Unless someone comes up with a better idea, I think simply overwriting the properties where we expect a certain value is an acceptable solution.

Apart from that I am not sure if the name of the command line option will result in the desired outcome of putting key key.serializer to the Map. Have you tested if Spring Boot maps this as you expected?

I verified that it works as expected. Btw.: I was more surprised that Spring Boot applies its transformation magic (changing to lower case and replacing underscores by dots) not only on the level of the variable names (the prefix) but additionally with the part that it uses as keys in the map (therefore I thought initially we could not provide generic environment variables here). But it works fine.
